intro: Brassica napus var. arabica, commonly known as Ethiopian mustard, is a variety of the oilseed rape species. It is native to the highlands of Ethiopia and is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and elongated, thin pods. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm and thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soil. Its seeds are used as a condiment and have a sharp, pungent flavor. The plant is also valued for its nutritional content, including high levels of essential oils and glucosinolates.
